channel.title: Stupid question
channel.description: I am trying make a new directory, but when I do, I just makes a blank file of what the folder should be named... I am using [code]File f = new File(System.getProperty("user.home") + File.seperator + "Blah").mkdirs();[/code]

item.title: Stupid question
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Scyth_, post:4, topic:468958”][quote author=imthenull link=topic=585980.msg4161345#msg4161345 date=1353133610]

firstly there is no constant or field called ‘seperator’ in the java.io.File class; i presume you were looking for the method System.getProperty(“file.seperator”) perhaps? secondly, File#mkdirs does not return a new instance of that class. if you even bothered looking at the documentation which i highly doubt you did (http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/File.html) you would find out that File#mkdirs actually returns a boolean. try again.

I don’t think you’ve read the documentation either, File.separator is a valid member of the File class.

The system-dependent default name-separator character, represented as a string for convenience.

Besides, how do you know that is not pseudo code? It may very well be. He said it ‘made a blank file’ therefore he compiled it.

@OP
You need to append another File.separator to the end of the directory name. File names ending in a path separator are directories.

[/quote]

Oh, see I looked at the other guys post and was confused as hell[/quote]

I was also as confused as fuuck when I couldn’t find it because I spelt it incorrectly.

Read full topic

item.title: Stupid question
item.dc:creator: @Scyth1 Scyth_
item.description:
@Scyth1 wrote:

[quote=“imthenull, post:3, topic:468958”][quote author=Whackatre link=topic=585980.msg4161339#msg4161339 date=1353131759]
firstly there is no constant or field called ‘seperator’ in the java.io.File class; i presume you were looking for the method System.getProperty(“file.seperator”) perhaps? secondly, File#mkdirs does not return a new instance of that class. if you even bothered looking at the documentation which i highly doubt you did (http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/File.html) you would find out that File#mkdirs actually returns a boolean. try again.
[/quote]
I don’t think you’ve read the documentation either, File.separator is a valid member of the File class.

The system-dependent default name-separator character, represented as a string for convenience.

Besides, how do you know that is not pseudo code? It may very well be. He said it ‘made a blank file’ therefore he compiled it.

@OP
You need to append another File.separator to the end of the directory name. File names ending in a path separator are directories.

Oh, see I looked at the other guys post and was confused as hell

Read full topic

firstly there is no constant or field called ‘seperator’ in the java.io.File class; i presume you were looking for the method System.getProperty(“file.seperator”) perhaps? secondly, File#mkdirs does not return a new instance of that class. if you even bothered looking at the documentation which i highly doubt you did (http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/io/File.html) you would find out that File#mkdirs actually returns a boolean. try again.

I don’t think you’ve read the documentation either, File.separator is a valid member of the File class.

The system-dependent default name-separator character, represented as a string for convenience.

Besides, how do you know that is not pseudo code? It may very well be. He said it ‘made a blank file’ therefore he compiled it.
